DOC.brief_summary: The purpose of this study is to test whether a dose of paracetamol given before surgical incision is more effective at reducing postoperative pain and analgesic consumption in cervical spine surgery versus a dose given at the end of surgery.
DOC.criteria: Aged 1880 years old Patients listed for nonmalignant cervical spinal surgery General anaesthesia Capacity to give informed consent Ability to use PCA device and pain score scale ASA I, II and III >50kg in weight Allergy or sensitivity to paracetamol, proparacetamol or morphine Liver disease Renal disease (creatinine clearance <30ml/min) Bleeding disorder Chronic alcoholism Chronic malnutrition Dehydration G6PD deficiency Hypernatraemia (Na >150) Hypokalaemia (K <3.5) and hyperchloraemia Pregnancy or breastfeeding
